column1: Abstract
European political elites are faced with a loss of trust and the emergence of a growing number of sometimes
rather obscure new political movements. How is this to be explained? What is the relationship between the
logic that guides political attitudes of constituencies and the logic of political actors whose legitimacy is
rooted in electoral choice of the constituencies? In this essay we approach this question from a systemic
perspective
column2: regarding this relationship as a problem solving feedback cycle. Classical approaches

column1: the median voter theorem
column2: view political actors as passively mirroring voters’ preferences. An alternative

column1: approach that we suggest
column2: assumes that the perception of competences of political actors on the part of

column1: constituencies is key in the sense that it does not only reflect voters’ preferences
column2: but it is also manipulable

column1: through the agency of political actors themselves. More generally
column2: we argue that the perception of

column1: competence is socially constructed and contextually dependent.
